PRINCE ALBERT.

REQUISITION!

To D. H. MACDOWALL, ESQ.,
PRINCE ALBERT.

SOUTH BRANCH, March, 1883.

Sir—

We, the undersigned residents of the South Branch Settlement, and representing our various interests, confidence in your integrity and ability and induce you to become a candidate to represent us as a member of the North West Council, for the District of Lorne, and in the event of your acceptance hereby pledge ourselves to support and vote for you at the coming election.

We are,

Yours respectfully,

Edward Taylor,
John H. Gordon,
George Tail,
William Leaskins,
Philip Turner,
Patrick Anderson,
Francis Fournier,
George Whitford,
George B. Whitford,
John Atwood,
Adam Johnston,
Robert Harper,
James B. Mack,
John Donald,
Peter Campbell,
Alexander McBeth,
Jeremiah Stevens,
J. E. W. Brown,
Bernard Brewer.

REPLY

PRINCE ALBERT, Feb. 27, 1883.

Gentlemen:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of this date, requesting me to claim myself to be brought forward as a candidate for the North West Council at the ensuing election.

I am prepared, in accordance to your request, and under the full conviction of my ability to further the interests not only of the District of Lorne, but of the entire North West, should I be called to represent you in the Council.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

D. H. MACDOWALL.
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
WEIDENSDAY, MAY 16, 1883.

OUR LANDS.
The want of tact displayed by the Government in dealing with our case is really dangerous, as it is likely to produce misunderstanding and confusion in the minds of those who are interested in the question. The delay in granting compensation and the lack of proper attention to all matters connected therewith are very serious. The interests of those parties who have been injured by the action of the Government are being neglected, and they are entitled to receive prompt and just compensation.

THE NOMINATIONS.
Before the next session of Parliament, the election of the District of Lewis will have taken place. The candidates for the representation of the District in the North West Council. What the outcome of an election will be cannot be foreseen. The respective candidates have held meetings in every part of the District, and the result of placing their claims fairly before the public has been most satisfactory. The claims which were presented in the beginning have been received with the utmost enthusiasm. The views and opinions of the people have been expressed in a manner which cannot be ignored. The claims have been fairly and impartially considered, and the result of the election will be known shortly.

EDITORIAL NOTES.
The question of the C.P.R. from the Pacific to the Atlantic is now being discussed in the House of Commons. The Government has promised to consider the matter at its earliest convenience. The question of the C.P.R. is of great importance to the country, and it is hoped that a decision will be reached soon.

ITEMS OF INTEREST.

PRINCE ALBERT, S.W.T.

Real Estate and General Agents,
Auctioneers, etc., etc.

Navigating from Quebec to the sea is now possible. Such vessels have been left for better times.

The line to unite the two Hudson's Bay companies has been referred to the railway and canal commissioners.

A return brought down from Grand Trunk Northwest under No. 1, containing 2,536 signatures.

The writer of the new election for that county will be named at once, and the election will take place as soon as the law will permit.—Poveshell Review.

It having been decided that certain crops of the East are suitable for the production of cotton, the Chamber of Commerce of Prince Albert has issued a circular in regard thereto.

Since on the Turtle Mountain is all gone. Spring floods are not as high as usual. Farmers in this vicinity are busy plowing and planting.

Construction contracts have been let on the Churchill, Salmo, and other rivers, and the work is progressing rapidly. Road travel is completely isolated several weeks.

Canal Survey will employ whether it is the intention of the Government to undertake the construction of canals for the supplementary claims of bad harbourage.

Mr. Wm. Macleod, C.E., is authority for the statement that there has not yet been a case of sickness among the men in the Manitoba Southwestern Railway to date.

A trump refused to saw wood for his dinner, giving as a reason that he was utterly unable to get out of the forest, and would do nothing to annoy anyone. He had been obliged to cut off pieces of his feet.

The death of the Postmaster and Postmistress has caused the following regretful obituary:—Postmaster, Andrew Allan, aged 78 years; Postmistress, Duncan Macintosh, of Winnipeg, 75 years.

Nearly eight hundred British conscripts arrived in Montreal April 18th en route for the North-West.

Mr. McCafferty introduced a bill to facilitate the transportation of goods through the North-Western Territories. The Bill has been referred to the Standing Committee.

It is stated that the consent of the King and Parliament must be obtained before the Canadian forces are to receive any part of their pay in money or coined French, which may very likely, according to the present state of affairs, be paid in kind.

There is no danger feared for the Canal at the present time, but perhaps, in the event of Indians invading, and even the possibility of an attack by the United States, the Canal might be closed.

The North-West, in view of the recent proclamation of the Nihilists, is very anxious to keep the peace in a peaceful way, and says that he is confident that the Canadian government will see that no such thing happens.

Government House,

OTTAWA, July 1882.

His Excellency the Governor General in Council,

On the recommendation of the Honorable Mr. Justice Borden, Minister of Indian Affairs, and under the provisions of the Royal Assent, given by His Excellency the Governor General in Council, pursuant to the provisions of Her Majesty's warrant, dated Ottawa, Canada, July 14th, 1882, and approved by the Senate of Canada, July 17th, 1882, and by and with the consent of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada, made by the said Mr. Justice Borden, pursuant to the provisions of the Royal Assent, and the same are hereby made and adopted.

In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the Great Seal of Canada, this tenth day of July, 1882.

GEORGE A. MILLER,

PROPRIETOR.

Farming Lands!

For Sale in Manitoba & North-west.

The Hudson's Bay Company own 7,000,000 acres in the Great Fertile Belt, and now offer for sale 300,000 acres, already surveyed by the Government of Canada.

ALSO Town Lots For Sale.

In Winnipeg, West Lynn, Rat Portage, Portage la Prairie and Goshen, N.W.T.

The above will be disposed of at reasonable prices and on easy terms of payment.

Full information in regard to these lands will be given at the offices of the Company in Winnipeg and Montreal.

C. J. FRYDEES, Land Commissioner.
